title: Tweeting PwC accountant blamed for Oscar best picture blunder

organizations.name: academy of motion picture arts and sciences

text:
M oments before he handed out the wrong envelope in one of the worst blunders in Oscar history, PwC accountant Brian Cullinan tweeted a behind-the-scenes photo of winner Emma Stone holding her just awarded statuette. "Best Actress Emma Stone backstage!" the tweet read.
Mr Cullinan botched the meticulous procedure for announcing the Oscar for best picture when he handed victory to La La Land before declaring Moonlight the real winner PwC, formerly Price Waterhouse Coopers, said on Monday.
Mr Cullinan was one of two accountants for PwC, formerly Price Waterhouse Coopers , tasked with doling out the envelopes containing winners' names to the presenters.
But in a gaffe that stunned the Dolby Theatre crowd in Hollywood and a television audience worldwide, " Cullinan mistakenly handed the back-up envelope for Actress in a Leading Role instead of the envelope for Best Picture " to Faye Dunaway and Warren Beatty, PwC said.
One of the two envelope holders tweeted this six minutes before the big mixup. Hasn't tweeted since. https://t.co/poeRvzh6jg 
— Ryan Beckler (@RyanBeckler) 27 February 2017 A ccording to the Wall Street Journal, Mr Cullinan posted the Stone photograph on Twitter at 9:05pm Pacific time, about three minutes before Dunaway and Beatty took the stage. 
The post was then deleted from Mr Cullinan’s account but Vocativ journalist, Ryan Beckler, tweeted a screengrab of it. A copy of the tweet was also kept by Google and available through a cache page.
PwC declined comment on Monday about whether Mr Cullinan's social media use may have distracted him, the Associated Press reported.
The Journal also quoted "a person familiar with the matter" saying that Mr Cullinan was turned down when he had sought permission to post to social media during the show.
Watch | Moonlight wins Best Picture after La La Land mistakenly named winner 02:06 M r Cullinan posted other photos on Twitter during the awards show that were also apparently deleted, the Journal quoted a "person with knowledge of the matter" as saying.
“This was our issue. PwC made the error, and we’re accountable,” said Tim Ryan, PwC’s US chairman, in an interview with the newspaper.
Watch | Emma Stone's amazing speech after to Best Picture mistake 00:48 M r Ryan said he has spoken to Mr Cullinan, who "doesn’t believe that a tweet caused the error". He added that Mr Cullinan said he feels “horrible, absolutely horrible”.
The accounting firm said on Monday that its staffers did not move quickly enough to correct the mistaken announcement of the best picture winner.
Three of the film's producers spoke before the actual winner, the coming-of-age drama Moonlight, was announced.
It took three hours for PwC, which has been overseeing Academy Awards balloting for 83 years, initially to confirm that Beatty and Dunaway received the wrong category envelope.
"PwC takes full responsibility for the series of mistakes and breaches of established protocols during last night's Oscars," PwC wrote. It said that Mr Cullinan mistakenly handed presenters Warren Beatty and Faye Dunaway an envelope containing the winner of the best actress award.
There are very few people who know the Oscar winners before Oscar Sunday. Find out all about those people by going to http://osca.rs/89ballots or click the link in our bio. 
A post shared by The Academy (@theacademy) on Feb 20, 2017 at 11:38am PST 
"Once the error occurred, protocols for correcting it were not followed through quickly enough by Mr. Cullinan or his partner," the statement read.
P wC had earlier released an apology to Beatty, Dunaway, the cast and crew of La La Land and Moonlight, and host Jimmy Kimmel .
"The presenters had mistakenly been given the wrong category envelope and when discovered, was immediately corrected. We are currently investigating how this could have happened, and deeply regret that this occurred."
As per protocol, Mr Cullinan and PwC colleague Martha Ruiz toted briefcases to the awards via the red carpet, each holding an identical set of envelopes for the show's 24 categories. The accountants also memorise the winners.
During the telecast, the accountants were stationed in the Dolby Theatre wings, one stage left and one stage right, to give presenters their category's envelope before they went on stage. Most presenters entered stage right, where Mr Cullinan was posted and where he handed Beatty and Dunaway the errant envelope.
#TBThursday - 87th Oscars Red Carpet. Our PwC group pic gets photo bombed first by Chrissy Teigen then hubby, John Legend. #pwc #Oscars pic.twitter.com/ETijDf3Xk9 
— Brian Cullinan (@briancullinan_) 24 February 2017 Y et the previous award, best actress, had been presented by Leonardo DiCaprio, who entered stage left and received the envelope from Ms Ruiz. That left a duplicate, unopened envelope for best actress at stage right.
"It's a simple process, if a painstaking one," said Dan Lyle, who had Oscar duties for Price Waterhouse for 11 years in the 1980s and '90s. Accountants attended rehearsals to learn whether presenters would enter from the right or left. But given the possibility of last-minute changes, both accountants had a full set of envelopes.
The accountancy firm had previously boasted that their 83-year contract had never come up for tender because they "always" do a good job, it has emerged.
The Academy is also reviewing the entire backstage process and PwC’s role in it, according to another person familiar with the matter, the Journal reported.
The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, which organises the Oscars, also apologised for the mishap and said it was committed to upholding the integrity of the Oscars.
"We have spent last night and today investigating the circumstances, and will determine what actions are appropriate going forward," it said in a statement.
